research.title: RESEARCH
research.catchphrase:
Ultrathin Film Technology
for Body-Harmonized Electronics
research.lead:
Based on nano- to micrometer-thick ultrathin materials and flexible electronic devices,
we are developing next-generation sensing and therapeutic systems that harmonize with biological tissues.

areas.title: Research Area 1: Electronic Nanopatch for Sports Applications

summary.challenge: sEMG measurement is difficult on high-friction areas like palms.
summary.approach: Use ultra-thin conductive polymer films as bioelectrodes.
summary.outcome: World-first palm sEMG recording during pitching.

description: Conventional wearable devices are obstructive when worn on sensitive areas of the body, such as the palms or soles, where friction is high, making it extremely challenging to measure muscle activity (surface electromyography, sEMG). To address this, we have developed an ultra-thin conductive polymer film (several hundred nm thick) that can be used as a "nano electronic patch" directly attached to the skin as a bioelectrode.

Due to its ultra-thinness and flexibility, the nano electronic patch adheres to the skin surface using only van der Waals forces, without requiring adhesives, and achieves comparable signal-to-noise ratios to commercially available gel electrodes for measuring sEMG. Furthermore, we developed new wearable and stretchable interconnects that do not hinder the wearer's natural movements and provide stable electrical connections even during intense physical activities. Combining this with the nano electronic patch, we successfully measured surface sEMG of the palm during baseball pitching, a world first.

areas.title: Research Area 2: Implantable Wireless Light-Emitting Device for Photodynamic Cancer Therapy

summary.challenge: Precise alignment is required for effective PDT.
summary.approach: Tissue-adhesive nanosheets with wirelessly powered LEDs.
summary.outcome: Sticker-like light sources stable on tissue surfaces.

description: Photodynamic therapy (PDT), which involves accumulating a photosensitizer at the tumor site and irradiating it with light to produce reactive oxygen species that kill cancer cells, requires the precise positioning of the tumor and light source. Thus, a stable, long-term light-emitting device that can be affixed to internal organs or tissues has been sought.

We developed a new polymer nanosheet modified with polydopamine, a compound mimicking the adhesive proteins secreted by mussels, greatly enhancing adhesion to biological tissues. Combining this nanosheet with a wirelessly powered LED, we created a light-emitting device that can be affixed to tissue surfaces like a sticker.

areas.title: Research Area 3: Ultra-thin Liquid Metal Devices for Conforming to Biological Tissues

summary.challenge: Thick substrates reduce flexibility and adhesion.
summary.approach: DIW 3D printing of liquid metal circuits on ultrathin elastomers.
summary.outcome: New design guidelines for conformable electronics.

description: Liquid metals such as EGaIn or Galinstan, primarily composed of gallium, are liquid at room temperature, exhibit low toxicity, and possess high electrical conductivity, making them ideal for developing stretchable electronic devices. However, thick substrates used in such devices have posed challenges in terms of flexibility and adhesion.

We established a new technique using Direct Ink Writing (DIW) 3D printing to form electronic circuits composed of liquid metals on ultra-thin silicone elastomer substrates, just a few microns thick. This technique is expected to provide new possibilities for the design and manufacture of flexible and stretchable electronic devices that can mechanically conform to humans, animals, and soft robots.

mission.title: MISSION
mission.catchphrase:
Creating Electronics
in Harmony with the Human Body
mission.description:
Through research on ultrathin materials and flexible electronic devices,
we aim to create new sensing and therapeutic technologies
that naturally harmonize with the human body.

We realize 'measure, connect, and heal' without interfering with natural body movements,
contributing to the future of healthcare, sports, and robotics.

steps.title: SCIENCE
steps.subtitle: Fundamental Research
steps.description: We elucidate the properties of nano- to micrometer-thick polymer thin films and build the foundation for new material designs that achieve both biocompatibility and functionality.

steps.title: TECHNOLOGY
steps.subtitle: Technology Development
steps.description: Leveraging insights from fundamental research, we develop practical elemental technologies such as bioelectrodes, wireless power transfer, and stretchable interconnects.

steps.title: APPLICATION
steps.subtitle: Social Implementation
steps.description: We deploy developed technologies to healthcare, sports, and robotics fields, contributing to solving social challenges.
